title_sort: bethuel smith to walt whitman, 28 september 1863
title: Bethuel Smith to Walt Whitman, 28 September 1863
text: Carlisle PennSept the 28 1863Dear FriendI now sit to write to you I hope this will find you in good spirits & well I received your letters & was verry[very] glad to get them & always shall be I am well the toe is getting along verry[very] fast I ware my boots A little everry[every] day I think in A few days I shall be able to join my regiment I hope so anyway for it is so loansome[lonesome] here to me I walk around considerable & the more I walk around the more loansom[lonesome] it is to me the buildings are all burnt & it looks dessolate[desolate] but they are repareing[repairing] them again Carlisle is miserabler[more miserable] than Washington for women I think friend walt[Walt] I should like to Come & see you verry[very] much I hope that I shall join my regimint[regiment] soon & then shall be near Washington where I Can come & see youDear friend I dont[don't] now as I have anny[any] more to write good by & may god bless you Bethuel Smith to Walt Whitman, 28 September 1863
